blocks.title: Research Participant Information and Consent Form (scroll down to review and agree to participate)
blocks.ask:
Title of the Study
Mapping People: Using MapStudy to Understand Interactive Maps and the Symbolization of People

Principal Investigators
Robert E. Roth, PhD 
375 Science Hall
550 N. Park Street
Madison, WI  53706
Phone: 608-262-1453; Email: reroth@wisc.edu

Meghan Kelly
Email: mkelly22@wisc.edu

Nick Lally
Email: nlally@wisc.edu

Description of Research
You are invited to participate in a study aimed at improving interactive web maps. Specifically, the study investigates how people are represented in interactive maps.

What will my participation involve?
If you decide to participate in this research, you will review two different case studies that include interactive maps. With each case study, you will be given a task to complete. After completing each task, you will respond to a survey of questions related to the case study, task, and the interactive map. The survey will take approximately 30 minutes to complete. You will be compensated $3 for your participation upon completing the survey.

Are there any risks to me?
Risk to participation is minimal. The case studies and interactive maps in this survey cover current news topics with no more detail than news outlets like the New York Times, for example. There are no foreseeable physical or mental risks to participation beyond those encountered in the normal course of everyday life.

Are there any benefits to me?
Your responses to the survey will be used to develop a better understanding of the design of interactive maps.

How will my confidentiality be protected?
No personally identifiable or sensitive information will be collected or maintained. Only group characteristics will be reported in publications of research findings.

Whom should I contact if I have questions?
You may ask any questions about the research at any time. If you have questions about the research after you leave today you should contact Robert E. Roth, PhD (PI) at 608-262-1453. If you are not satisfied with response of research team, have more questions, or want to talk with someone about your rights as a research participant, you should contact the Education Research and Social & Behavioral Science IRB Office at 608-263-2320. Your participation is completely voluntary and you can withdraw from the study at any time without compensation.

If you do NOT agree to take part in this research study as outline above, please Exit this survey.

If you agree to take part in this research study as outlined above, please click 'Next' below. By selecting 'Next' you agree to the following statement: I understand my rights as a participant and agree to participate in this research Study

blocks.title: Overview, Eligibility, and Instructions (scroll down to review and continue)
blocks.ask:
Thank you for agreeing to participate!

Maps are used on a daily basis at unprecedented levels. You may be familiar with mapping applications like Apple Maps, Google Maps, and MapQuest. You may also make use of web maps in social media like Facebook, Foursquare, Instagram, and Twitter. Further, you might have explored more complex interactive maps in popular news outlets like the New York Times and the Washington Post. The purpose of this study is to learn how we should create interactive maps that represent people.

Instructions
  • In Part 1, you will be presented with a case study. After you read the case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions will be multiple choice, ranking, and short answer.
  • In Part 2, you will be presented with a second case study. After you read the second case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions will be multiple choice, ranking, and short answer.
  • In Part 3 will be given a series of interactive maps and will ask you to rank them.
You will be compensated after completing these three sections and an exit survey!

Interactive Maps
Each interactive map allows you to Zoom, Pan, and Retreive Pop Ups. Learn how to zoom, pan, and use retreive pop ups on example maps below.

Zoom


Pan


Retrieve Pop Ups

Eligibility
Before beginning, please once review your eligibility for participating in the study. These restrictions greatly impact your responses.
  • You must be 18 years of age or older.
  • You must be fluent in English.
  • You must currently be living in the United States.
  • You must complete the survey on a non-mobile device, such as a laptop or desktop computer. Completing the experiment on a smartphone or small screen tablet will greatly impact your performance and skew results.
If you have read the instructions and confirm that you are eligible, select 'Next' below to begin.

blocks.title: Oakland Case Study Introduction
blocks.ask:
In the past three years, a number of police killings in the United States have received widespread media attention, sparking national debates on law enforcement practices. The killing of unarmed black men in particular have given rise to massive protests and activist movements across the country. The killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Eric Garner in New York City, Walter Scott in South Carolina, and Freddie Gray in Baltimore, to name a few, all received sustained media attention. Statistics on police killings in the United States, however, are not recorded by the government.

In response, some journalists have begun investigating the extent of the issue. Media outlets like the Washington Post and the Guardian (United Kingdom) have began to compile statistics on police killings using public records, news reports, and crowdsourcing. The Guardian estimates that over 1000 people were killed each year by police in 2015 and 2016. James Comey, head of the FBI, said that it was 'embarrassing and ridiculous' that media sources had better information on this issue than the US Government. California, the most populous state, leads the nation in killings by police. In Oakland, California, one of the largest cities in California, an estimated 104 people were killed by police between 2000 and 2017.

blocks.title: Aleppo Case Study Introduction
blocks.ask:
Since March of 2011, Syria has faced civil unrest leading to what the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) calls 'the biggest humanitarian emergency of our era.' Peaceful protests began in early 2011 after a group of teenagers were detained and tortured for painting revolutionary propaganda publically in the city of Dar’a. The situation quickly escalated with violent backlash from the Syrian government under President Bashar al-Assad. The backlash committed by the Assad government has preempted a Syrian civil war leading to over 400,000 lives lost, five million registered refugees, and six million internally displaced in Syria.

Prior to the conflict, Aleppo was Syria’s largest city and the heart of Syrian finance and industry. Since 2012, Aleppo has become a focal point and key battleground site throughout the duration of the conflict. Strict divisions between Assad regime-controlled areas and opposition-controlled areas quickly emerged. Bombing between both sides has destroyed crucial infrastructure such as homes, schools, and hospitals killing thousands of people throughout the city. Over 100,000 civilians remained trapped in Aleppo as violence steadily increased in late 2016.

blocks.title: Part 1
blocks.ask: In Part 1, you will be presented with a case study. After you read the case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions will be multiple choice, ranking, and short answer.

blocks.title: Part 2
blocks.ask: In Part 2, you will be presented with a second case study. After you read the second case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions will be multiple choice, ranking, and short answer.

blocks.title: Part 3
blocks.ask: In Part 3 will be given a series of interactive maps and will ask you to rank them.

blocks.title: Exit Survey
blocks.ask: Please complete this exit survey to receive compensation.

blocks.title: Oakland Case Study (scroll to view all questions)

blocks.ask: In order to monitor interactions between police and Oakland residents, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) is developing plans for a police oversight center in the city. This center will allow for the quick deployment of legal observers to incidents involving the police. These observers will be called on to act as witnesses in legal cases while generating valuable data for the city to assess law enforcement practices. The ACLU has proposed potential locations for the center.
1. Using the map legend above, the five potential sites, and the casualty distribution provided in the interactive map, determine which location would be best suited for the new center.
2. Rank each potential site from least suitable to most suitable.
Site 1 (1 = Least Suitable and 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 2 (1 = Least Suitable and 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 3 (1 = Least Suitable and 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 4 (1 = Least Suitable and 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 5 (1 = Least Suitable and 5 = Most Suitable)

blocks.title: Aleppo Survey Questions (scroll to view all questions)
blocks.ask: The words below describe different feelings and emotions. Please rank each word from 1 to 5 based on your current feelings and emotions after viewing the previous map. Rank each word based on the extent to which you feel the word right now.
Interested (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Distressed (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Excited (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Upset (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Strong (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Guilty (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Scared (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Hostile (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Enthusiastic (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Proud (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Irritable (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Alert (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Ashamed (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Inspired (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Nervous (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Determined (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Attentive (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Jittery (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Active (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)
Afraid (1 = Slightly and 5 = Extremely)

blocks.title: Aleppo Survey Questions

blocks.ask: 1. Who was included in the map? Is there a particular person or group of people that stood out to you, and why?
2. How do you feel about the people in the map? Did your emotional state change while looking and interacting with the map?
3. Why were the people in the map relatable or not relatable? How could the map be improved to make the people in the map more relatable?

blocks.title: Exit Survey
blocks.ask: Please rank the following: (scroll to view all questions)
Should the US create new programs to combat racial inequities?
Should the US decrease funding for existing programs that combat racial inequities?
Should the US create new social programs for incoming immigrants?
Should the US decrease funding for existing social programs that help incoming immigrants?
Should the US create new programs for national security and military?
Should the US decrease funding for existing national security and military programs?
Should the US create new programs for social welfare?
Should the US decrease funding for existing social welfare programs?
Should the US create new programs for environmental protection?
Should the US decrease funding for environmental protection programs?

You will be compensated after completing these three sections and an exit survey!

Interactive Maps
Each interactive map allows you to Zoom, Pan, and Retreive Pop Ups. Learn how to zoom, pan, and use retreive pop ups on example maps below.

Zoom


Pan


Retrieve Pop Ups

Eligibility
Before beginning, please once review your eligibility for participating in the study. These restrictions greatly impact your responses.
  • You must be 18 years of age or older.
  • You must be fluent in English.
  • You must currently be living in the United States.
  • You must complete the survey on a non-mobile device, such as a laptop or desktop computer. Completing the experiment on a smartphone or small screen tablet will greatly impact your performance and skew results.
If you have read the instructions and confirm that you are eligible, select 'Next' below to begin.

blocks.title: Overview, Eligibility, and Instructions (scroll down to review and continue)
blocks.ask:
Thank you for agreeing to participate!

Maps are used on a daily basis at unprecedented levels. You may be familiar with mapping applications like Apple Maps, Google Maps, and MapQuest. You may also make use of web maps in social media like Facebook, Foursquare, Instagram, and Twitter. Further, you might have explored more complex interactive maps in popular news outlets like the New York Times and the Washington Post. The purpose of this study is to learn how we should create interactive maps that represent people.

Instructions

You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions will be multiple choice, ranking, and short answer.
